PlotA Child Called “It” by Dave Pelzer was a true story about the survival of a child that was one of the worst child abuse cases ever reported. David Pelzer had been starved and also suffered from torture, which began when he was four years old. David was only allowed to eat the leftovers of his brother's cereal. His mother would never drive him to school. He would normally be forced to run to school. David was called to the nurse's office because someone reported his injuries to her. This had become a routine that way she was able to look at his injuries. One of the times the nurse called in the principal due to the extent of his injuries. David's mother had started to drink and was becoming depressed. During her drinking binges, his mother had taken out her negative feelings on David. It quickly progressed to beatings. One of these beatings caused David to get a broken arm. Soon, the abuse started to turn into mental punishments. When his mother gave birth to two more boys, the punishments had become harsher. David was excluded from all family events. Oftentimes, David was not even allowed to sleep in the house. His mother never tried to hide the abuse she had done to her son. She forced him to go to school in clothes he had been wearing for months at a time and told him what to tell to anyone who asked about his bruises. When teachers became suspicious, his mother had given excuses to get out of interviews or she convinced David the worst was over, and that she would never hurt him again. When his father was home, the punishments were never as severe. David lost hope of being saved and thought he would be stuck with his “family” forever. He eventually stopped caring about avoiding his mother's rage. Months after David found the strength to pray, he was rescued by teachers at his elementary school. David grew up, became a father, and made peace with the horrible abuse he suffered as a child.CharacterizationDavid Pelzer was only four years old when the book started. He lived with his abusive mother and father who hadn’t done anything to stop the abuse that occured. While he lived in that household, he had to figure out how to outsmart his mother. It was very rare that his attempts were successful. David had to have a strong mindset in order to get through the abuse, but it was hard at times. Near the end of the book, David had thought about what it would be like to have a different life.David’s mother had loved all of her children. Something had switched and she had begun to go on drinking binges and would act completely different towards David. She was not the same to his other brothers. She would not let David eat, sleep indoors, and send him to school in clothing he had already been wearing for months. Throughout the book, her abuse had escalated and she had taken away any source of comfort David had left. SettingThis book took place in Daly City, California during 1970. During this time, child abuse had been unnoticed and was ignored a majority of the time due to the author’s school being fairly large. Social services Abuse left a huge mark on David Pelzer’s life because it happened to him. He felt the pain of child abuse first-hand from his parents.Thematic ConnectionOvercoming child abuse was a huge theme of this book. It was prevalent because the author explained how his whole childhood revolved around the constant abuse he had gone through and how it shaped his life. He described how his mother made him wear clothing he had already worn for months. He also stated he had told his teachers stories of how he got his bruises.RecommendationI would recommend this book to any high school student. I gave this recommendation because it was a very mature book with mature content that should not be read by younger students. "A Child Called It" by Dave Pelzer is truly an inspirational story. The book follows Dave's (David) young childhood in one of the most severe child abuse cases in California. Even though at the time David was only in elementary school he constantly shows maturity, determination, and imagination through his unspeakable times, making him someone people could aspire to be. This book talks about some severe topics and situations. There also is a little coarse language and so although this book my not be appropriate for younger children, I completely recommend it. The story shows David’s determination, perseverance, and willpower to overcome his rough family life. In the end readers see that he does as Dave and his son go back to the vacation spot where his mom took his abuse to the next level.In his early years, David was so happy. He had happy parents and siblings. He played a lot and loved going on vacations with his strong dad and beautiful mother. One day, as his parents fought and drank more and more, the punishments began. It started with an occasional timeout and being called a bad boy, but gradually, the punishments escalated to hitting and torturous “games”. David was even held back in first grade because his mother didn’t believe he should be able to pass. Soon David was no longer considered part of the family. He did all the chores and when he wasn’t doing that, he was told to wait on the stairs to the garage and not move. He wasn’t allowed to play, talk, or even look at his siblings, and wasn’t allowed to eat with the family. He was also timed when doing chores and if he didn’t finish in time, he was punished and deprived of food. David constantly looked up to his father and felt that his father was his protector. His mother never hurt David in front of him, and his father always tried to help. This resulted in them fighting even more and eventually, his dad left. His mother blamed him for this and the punishments got worse. Some of her games included him sitting on the stove and getting burned, getting his little brothers dirty diapers thrown at him and having to eat it, and always being deprived of food.At school David would be made fun of for his looks and smells, but he really didn’t care. He was constantly in trouble for stealing kids food and always tried to find new ways to get food. This resulted in more punishments and more abuse from his mother. Some times the abuse was so bad he would cough blood. He was even stabbed once. Through this all David never broke. He never let his mom win in her games. He always kept going.After years of this, David showing up to school with bruises, cuts, bumps etc. him lying to the nurse about where they came from and always going through the same routines, the excuses didn’t work. When the nurse brought it up, David was called down to the teachers lounge. In there the nurse, principal, teachers, and a police man questioned him about where he got them. David reluctantly told the truth and was taken away. He was put into foster care and never dealt with that abuse again. This book was not an easy read, and dealt with very real and serious topics. I would still recommend it because it teaches you that no matter what happened in your past, you can choose to give up or keep fighting like David did. “A Child Called “It”” , by David Pelzer is a story about a young boy who throughout his childhood was severely abused by his mother. The young boy and main character of this tragic and true story is David Pelzer himself this book is an autobiography written by David Pelzer about the life threatening challenges he was faced with at a very young age. David once had a very normal and perhaps happy life, he had a family with his two brothers, mother, and father, he lived in a nice house and was loved. But as the story develops readers come to the tragic realization that life for David will not remain that way. The change between the love and hatred that David was given developed slowly that its hard to spot exact places where David did anything to deserve what his future held. He still lived in the same house but that seemed to be the only thing that remained from his former life, David now lived with a father who watched him get nearly killed, made promises he couldn’t keep, drank much more often, was rarely home, and who listened to the sick and twisted ways of his wife blaming things on David just like the rest of the family. His two brothers now saw him through the eyes their mother had forced them to treating him like trash and never showing him any sympathy, and worst of all his once loving, fun, and nurturing mother was now a monster and someone he would never love again she caused him pain to the point were he almost died many times and when he wasn’t near death he wished he was just to escape her. She beat him and starved him out of pleasure and frequently called him a bad boy punishing him for things such as responding the wrong way or not cleaning fast enough. She hated her own son and often expressed that through her actions and words and caused all his other family members to also hate him leaving him alone and helpless in a hell hole that had once been his home. Her sick and horrifying games took everything away from David causing him to see things as food and simple interactions as luxuries. The only reason he survived was because he grew used to the ways of his mother behaviors and how that would effect the level of abuse he would endure that day, he had reactions he knew would please her, and limited but some defense. But mainly he had the hope of potentially escaping, this hope was found in his dreams where his father would come to safe him and take him away from his mother forever or he would find a new family who truly did love him. Although as the story continued this hope slowly yet noticeably disappeared and it seems along side this his chances of survival do also. Yet readers wonder does his hope, faith, and determination have the power to safe his life?I don’t know who to recommend this book to on the basis of enjoyment as it is a book about child abuse so it focuses on some hard topics that are tragic in our world today. But I do recommend this book because of the fact that it is well written and the hard topics it focuses on are something we should all acknowledge and correct. Anyone looking for an autobiography and would like to read a first hand view of what a person being abused feels like and has to go through and their struggle to survive can find that within this book. Although it is sad and horrible to think someone could do these things to another person this book is good and I feel I benefited from reading it. One writing technique the author used that I liked was how he began the first chapter with the events that would occur in the end and then gave the backstory throughout the majority of the book, I liked this because it allowed readers to build our own characters and views about them before actually being told who they were. It also showed that no matter how bad it got for our main character eventually he would survive. Another writing technique was the amount of detail used to describe the emotions and thoughts of the main character, since the author had experienced his story first hand he was able to go past making a character to writing every fear and thought the main character had since it was him as a small boy who I doubt could forget the details of such a traumatic experience. Being told these all of things allowed us to really get to know the main character and build a connection with him throughout the book, readers will fight for him all the way through the end. Although most people haven’t had to endure what David has readers get a glimpse into how terrifying it really is. I gave this book a 4/5 because although it was well written and overall a good book, I do not believe it was perfect and the constant seriousness of the danger David’s life was in can cause some people to think perhaps parts could’ve been made up to improve the story. Although I don’t believe that it makes you wonder could a human being be capable of this much torture to her own son?

A Child Called "It," but David Pelzer is not an easy book to read. The book chronicles several years of the early life of David Pelzer. In his first four years of life, his world is almost idyllic. David’s mother is a stay at home mom who loves her children. David father is a fireman and loves his kids. David’s loves playing with his older brothers. However, at the age of four David’s mother had a dramatic and bizarre change in personality and specifically in how she viewed and treated David. The book never explains our attempts to analyze the mother’s mental condition, but her behavior becomes sadistic toward her youngest son for the next eight years of his life. David’s mother had a serious drinking problem, but even in the light of this problem how she treated David as compared to all her other children is bizarre. David’s mother continued to show a level of respect toward her husband and other children – or at least relative to how she treated David.David’s father was too weak to stand up to his wife. In the early years he tried to support David or argue his case, but eventually, he put up the flag of surrender. Over time his mother's mistreatment of David takes a toll on David’s family. Eventually, the marriage breaks up, and David is left with no hope of a protector as his father moves out.To say the mother treated the family dog better does not capture depravation of her behavior toward David. The range of torture applied to David seemed only to be limited by her imagination. The acts included burning him on the stove, stabbing him, poisoning his with Clorox and ammonia, and much more. Through all this abuse David was relegated to be the family serf – he did not eat with the family, he was forced to sleep in the cold garage, and often was not fed for days at a time. David was expected to work for his mother daily. His assigned tasks often had time limits with the punishment of no food if he did not complete the work in the set time. David is saved by one of his teachers when he is twelve and is removed from the family. This book is the first in a series of 3 by Pelzer – so I will have to read the next book to learn how he makes out in the next stage of his life. However, the book's epilogue makes it is clear that David was able to survive his extreme abuse, join the U.S. Airforce and have a family of his own. Many other “Davids” do not survive the abuse and if they do, they are not able to enjoy the success David obtains in his life. Though this book is very difficult to read of, I am glad I did. Understanding that children today are in similar situations to what David endured is an education we all need.
